item.title: Awesome Agentic Patterns: A Curated Catalogue of Production-Ready AI Agent Patterns
Claude Skills in 15 Minutes: AI Will's Step-by-Step Tutorial for Non-Technical Users
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Claude Code has revolutionized how developers interact with AI, but many users are intimidated by the concept of ‚ÄúSkills‚Äù ‚Äî custom capabilities that extend Claude‚Äôs functionality. AI Will (@FinanceYF5), a growth consultant and AI industry analyst, has created a comprehensive tutorial that breaks down this barrier, enabling non-technical users to set up Claude Skills in just 15 minutes.

This blog post explores AI Will‚Äôs approach and provides additional context to help you get started with Claude Skills quickly and confidently.

What Are Claude Skills?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Are Claude Skills?‚Äù

Claude Skills are reusable, custom capabilities that you can create to extend Claude Code‚Äôs functionality. Think of them as personal tools that automate repetitive tasks, encode your preferences, or integrate with external services. Skills can range from simple text formatting utilities to complex multi-step workflows.

Why Skills Matter

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Skills Matter‚Äù

According to research from METR (mentioned in Reza Rezvani‚Äôs analysis), developers using AI tools often complete tasks slower than those without AI, while paradoxically rating their productivity higher. This productivity gap exists because users focus on generating more code rather than building reusable capabilities that compound over time.

Skills are the solution to this problem. They transform one-off prompts into persistent, refinable tools that actually accelerate your workflow.

AI Will‚Äôs 15-Minute Approach

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Will‚Äôs 15-Minute Approach‚Äù

AI Will‚Äôs tutorial, shared across multiple X (Twitter) threads, emphasizes accessibility above all else. The core philosophy is that Claude Skills should not be intimidating ‚Äî despite appearances, they are remarkably simple to set up.

Key Principles

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Principles‚Äù
  1. Start Simple: Begin with basic skills that solve immediate problems
  2. Learn by Doing: The tutorial is hands-on, not theoretical
  3. Non-Technical Friendly: No coding background required
  4. 15-Minute Target: Setup time should fit in a short break

The Tutorial Structure

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Tutorial Structure‚Äù

Based on AI Will‚Äôs threads and the ecosystem of Claude Skills tutorials, here‚Äôs the recommended learning path:

Step 1: Understanding the Skills Directory

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 1: Understanding the Skills Directory‚Äù

Claude Code stores skills in a .claude/skills directory within your project. Each skill is a markdown file with a specific structure:

Step 2: Your First Skill

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 2: Your First Skill‚Äù

The most common starting point is a simple skill that encodes your coding preferences. For example:

File: .claude/skills/code-style.md

Step 3: Testing and Iteration

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 3: Testing and Iteration‚Äù

Activate your skill by referencing it in conversation: ‚ÄúUse my code-style skill.‚Äù Claude will apply those preferences automatically. Iterate based on results.

Common Use Cases for Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Use Cases for Skills‚Äù

1. Project Conventions

Section titled ‚Äú1. Project Conventions‚Äù

Encode your team‚Äôs coding standards so Claude generates compliant code automatically.

2. Workflow Automation

Section titled ‚Äú2. Workflow Automation‚Äù

Create multi-step workflows like ‚Äúrun tests, lint, and generate a PR description‚Äù as a single skill invocation.

3. External Integrations

Section titled ‚Äú3. External Integrations‚Äù

Skills can include shell commands, allowing integration with your development tools.

4. Personal Preferences

Section titled ‚Äú4. Personal Preferences‚Äù

Your preferred file organization, naming patterns, or documentation style can be encoded once and reused forever.

Resources and Community

Section titled ‚ÄúResources and Community‚Äù

AI Will‚Äôs tutorial is part of a broader ecosystem of Claude Skills resources:

  • Claude Skills Overview: 3-step quickstart with real-world scenarios
  • The Claude Skills Factory: Building production-ready AI tools
  • Claude Code for Non-Coders: Complete beginner‚Äôs guide (YouTube)
  • Claude Code Skills: Automate Everything: Six-step framework (YouTube)

Getting Started

Section titled ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù

Ready to build your first skill? Here‚Äôs the quickest path:

  1. Open your terminal and navigate to a Claude Code project
  2. Create the skills directory: mkdir -p .claude/skills
  3. Create your first skill: echo '# Hello World Skill' > .claude/skills/hello.md
  4. Test it: In Claude Code, type ‚ÄúUse the hello skill‚Äù

From there, explore AI Will‚Äôs full tutorial for comprehensive guidance on building more complex skills.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Claude Skills are the key to unlocking Claude Code‚Äôs full potential. AI Will‚Äôs 15-minute tutorial removes the intimidation factor and provides a clear path for users of all technical backgrounds. By investing just 15 minutes, you can begin building a library of reusable capabilities that will pay dividends in every future session.

The barrier to entry is low ‚Äî the only limit is your imagination.

Sources

Section titled ‚ÄúSources‚Äù
  • AI Will (@FinanceYF5) on X
  • Claude Skills Overview - Vibe Sparking
  • The Claude Skills Factory - Medium
  • Claude Code for Non-Coders - YouTube
  • Claude Code Skills: Automate Everything - YouTube
  • How to Set Up Claude Skills in <15 Minutes - Reddit

item.title: Claude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work
item.content:encoded:
Claude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work

Section titled ‚ÄúClaude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work‚Äù

Source: @dr_cintas | Published: January 6, 2026

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

In a recent viral thread, Alvaro Cintas declared that ‚ÄúClaude Skills are crazy useful‚Äù and shared 10 skills that can fundamentally transform how you work. The response from the developer community has been overwhelming - users like Farhan noted that ‚Äúskills being just markdown files is the best part. i don‚Äôt want to learn a proprietary sdk just to teach my bot a new trick.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt just another AI feature. Skills represent a paradigm shift in how we extend and customize AI capabilities. Let‚Äôs dive deep into what makes Claude Skills so powerful and explore the ecosystem that‚Äôs rapidly evolving around them.

What Are Claude Skills?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Are Claude Skills?‚Äù

Claude Skills are modular, self-contained packages that extend Claude‚Äôs capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, and tools. They‚Äôre essentially folders containing:

  • Instructions (markdown files that tell Claude what to do)
  • Scripts (executable code for specific tasks)
  • Resources (supporting files and configurations)

The beauty lies in their simplicity:

Why Skills Matter

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Skills Matter‚Äù
  1. Zero Learning Curve - Skills are just markdown files. No proprietary SDK required
  2. On-Demand Loading - Skills load only when needed, so you can maintain hundreds without performance impact
  3. Composability - Multiple skills can run together for complex workflows
  4. Shareability - Easy to create, modify, and distribute

10 Essential Claude Skills That Change How You Work

Section titled ‚Äú10 Essential Claude Skills That Change How You Work‚Äù

Based on the official anthropics/skills repository and community contributions, here are the standout skills:

1. Document Creation Suite

Section titled ‚Äú1. Document Creation Suite‚Äù

Official Skills: docx, pptx, xlsx, pdf

Create professional documents without leaving Claude:

  • docx - Generate, edit, and analyze Word documents
  • pptx - Build PowerPoint presentations with proper formatting
  • xlsx - Work with Excel spreadsheets, analyze data
  • pdf - Extract text, create PDFs, handle forms

These skills transform Claude from a chat interface into a full document production suite.

2. Systematic Debugging

Section titled ‚Äú2. Systematic Debugging‚Äù

Source: obra/superpowers

The Systematic Debugging skill is arguably underrated. As one user noted:

‚ÄúHaving Claude follow a structured root cause ‚Üí hypothesis ‚Üí fix flow instead of randomly trying things makes it so much more reliable for complex bugs.‚Äù

This skill teaches Claude to:

  1. Define the problem clearly
  2. Form hypotheses
  3. Test systematically
  4. Document findings
  5. Verify the fix

3. Rube Connector

Section titled ‚Äú3. Rube Connector‚Äù

500+ Apps Integration

Yinan Na highlighted: ‚ÄúRube connector letting you hit 500 apps through one setup is such a time saver‚Äù

Rube is an MCP server that connects Claude to over 500 business applications:

  • Gmail, Slack, Notion
  • GitHub, Linear, Airtable
  • And hundreds more

One unified interface for workflow automation across your entire stack.

4. n8n Workflow Skills

Section titled ‚Äú4. n8n Workflow Skills‚Äù

Source: czlonkowski/n8n-skills

Seven complementary skills for building production-ready n8n workflows:

  • n8n-code-javascript - JavaScript in Code nodes
  • n8n-code-python - Python coding in n8n
  • n8n-expression-syntax - Master n8n expressions
  • n8n-mcp-tools-expert - MCP tools integration
  • n8n-node-configuration - Node dependency rules
  • n8n-validation-expert - Fix validation errors
  • n8n-workflow-patterns - Proven workflow patterns

5. Skill Creator Meta-Skill

Section titled ‚Äú5. Skill Creator Meta-Skill‚Äù

Official: anthropics/skill-creator

The skill that creates skills! This meta-skill guides you through:

  • Understanding skill structure
  • Writing effective instructions
  • Adding executable scripts
  • Testing and validation

6. Web Artifacts Builder

Section titled ‚Äú6. Web Artifacts Builder‚Äù

Official: anthropics/web-artifacts-builder

Build complex HTML artifacts with React and Tailwind CSS directly in Claude. Perfect for:

  • Rapid prototyping
  • Interactive demos
  • Client presentations
  • Proof-of-concepts

7. Context Engineering Skills

Section titled ‚Äú7. Context Engineering Skills‚Äù

Source: muratcankoylan/Agent-Skills-for-Context-Engineering

Advanced skills for managing context in agent systems:

  • context-fundamentals - Understanding context anatomy
  • context-degradation - Recognizing failure patterns
  • context-compression - Compression strategies
  • context-optimization - Compaction and caching
  • memory-systems - Short and long-term memory
  • multi-agent-patterns - Orchestration architectures

8. Git Workflow Skills

Section titled ‚Äú8. Git Workflow Skills‚Äù

Source: fvadicamo/dev-agent-skills

Streamline your development workflow:

  • git-commit - Conventional Commits automation
  • github-pr-creation - PR creation automation
  • github-pr-merge - Merge workflow management
  • github-pr-review - Code review assistance

9. Algorithmic Art

Section titled ‚Äú9. Algorithmic Art‚Äù

Official: anthropics/algorithmic-art

Create generative art using p5.js with seeded randomness. Perfect for:

  • Unique visual assets
  • Brand materials
  • Creative projects
  • Exploring generative design

10. Test Driven Development

Section titled ‚Äú10. Test Driven Development‚Äù

Source: obra/superpowers

Teaches Claude to write tests BEFORE implementing code:

  • Test-first approach
  • TDD best practices
  • Test refactoring
  • Coverage analysis

Community Reactions

Section titled ‚ÄúCommunity Reactions‚Äù

The developer community has embraced Skills enthusiastically:

@mhdfaran: ‚Äúskills being just markdown files is the best part. i don‚Äôt want to learn a proprietary sdk just to teach my bot a new trick.‚Äù

@Meer_AIIT: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been using it for a while for a different usecases and my life is now too good I‚Äôve automated most of my work with Claude skills.‚Äù

@antefex_moon: ‚ÄúOne really cool pattern I picked up from Anthropic‚Äôs official skill examples on GitHub: attach utility scripts to skills.‚Äù

Why Skills Beat Traditional Approaches

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Skills Beat Traditional Approaches‚Äù

vs MCP Servers

Section titled ‚Äúvs MCP Servers‚Äù

While MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers are powerful for external integrations, Skills excel at:

  • Behavior modification - Teach Claude HOW to think
  • Workflow patterns - Encode best practices
  • Domain knowledge - Project-specific conventions
  • Zero infrastructure - No servers to deploy

vs Custom Prompts

Section titled ‚Äúvs Custom Prompts‚Äù

Skills offer advantages over ad-hoc prompting:

  • Reusability - Write once, use everywhere
  • Version control - Track changes over time
  • Team sharing - Distribute consistent behaviors
  • Composability - Combine multiple skills

Getting Started with Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúGetting Started with Skills‚Äù

Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation‚Äù

Skills are placed in your .claude/skills/ directory:

Creating Your First Skill

Section titled ‚ÄúCreating Your First Skill‚Äù
  1. Create a folder in .claude/skills/
  2. Add a SKILL.md file with instructions
  3. Optionally add scripts or resources
  4. Restart Claude - your skill is now available!

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù
  1. Start Small - Focus on one specific capability
  2. Be Explicit - Claude follows instructions literally
  3. Test Thoroughly - Verify edge cases
  4. Document Well - Help others (and future you) understand
  5. Version Control - Track changes in git

The Growing Ecosystem

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Growing Ecosystem‚Äù

The Skills ecosystem is expanding rapidly:

  • awesome-claude-skills - Curated list of community skills
  • Claude Skills Hub - Directory of skills
  • Claude Skills Learning Center - Tutorials and guides

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Claude Skills represent a fundamental shift in AI customization. By being:

  • Simple (just markdown files)
  • Powerful (executable code + instructions)
  • Composable (multiple skills together)
  • Shareable (easy to distribute)

They‚Äôre enabling a new generation of AI-powered workflows that were previously impossible.

As the community continues to build and share skills, we‚Äôre seeing the emergence of a vibrant ecosystem of specialized AI capabilities. Whether you‚Äôre automating document creation, streamlining development workflows, or connecting to hundreds of external services, there‚Äôs probably already a skill for that.

The future of AI isn‚Äôt just about better models - it‚Äôs about better ways to customize and extend them. Claude Skills are leading that charge.

Resources

Section titled ‚ÄúResources‚Äù

Official Documentation

Section titled ‚ÄúOfficial Documentation‚Äù
  • Claude Skills Quickstart
  • Skills Cookbook
  • Official Skills Repository

Community Resources

Section titled ‚ÄúCommunity Resources‚Äù
  • awesome-claude-skills
  • Claude Skills Hub
  • Simon Willison on Claude Skills

Featured Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúFeatured Skills‚Äù
  • n8n Skills
  • Obra Superpowers
  • Context Engineering Skills

item.title: Context Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong
item.content:encoded:
Context Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong

Section titled ‚ÄúContext Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong‚Äù

Source: @KirkMarple | Published: January 6, 2026

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

The context graph conversation has exploded over the past two weeks. Foundation Capital‚Äôs ‚ÄúContext Graphs: AI‚Äôs Trillion-Dollar Opportunity‚Äù kicked it off. Animesh Koratana‚Äôs thread on coordinate systems deepened the technical framing. Daniel Davis published ‚ÄúThe Context Graph Manifesto‚Äù connecting it to the semantic web‚Äôs heritage.

The conversation is valuable. The questions being asked‚Äîhow do we give agents organizational memory? how do we capture decision traces? how do we build systems that learn from how work actually happens?‚Äîare the right questions.

But Kirk Marple, who has been building context infrastructure for over three years, argues there‚Äôs a false dichotomy emerging that misses the point entirely.

The False Dichotomy

Section titled ‚ÄúThe False Dichotomy‚Äù

The current conversation has crystallized around a binary choice: prescribed ontologies vs learned ontologies.

On one side: Palantir. The argument goes that Palantir built a $400B+ company on prescribed ontologies‚Äîdefine the schema upfront, map messy enterprise data into it, deploy forward engineers to customize it for each customer. It works, but it‚Äôs expensive, slow, and doesn‚Äôt scale.

On the other side: The future. Learned ontologies. Structure that emerges from how work actually happens rather than how someone designed it to happen. Agent trajectories as training data. Decision traces that compile into organizational world models. The ontology isn‚Äôt declared‚Äîit‚Äôs discovered.

As Jaya Gupta recently wrote:

‚ÄúThe next $50B company will be built on learned ontologies. Structure that emerges from how work actually happens, not how you designed it to happen‚Ä¶ Memory assumes you know what to store and how to retrieve it. But the most valuable context is structure you didn‚Äôt know existed until agents discovered it through use.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs the problem: This framing ignores twenty years of ontology work that already exists.

The Third Option: Adopt, Then Learn

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Third Option: Adopt, Then Learn‚Äù

What‚Äôs missing from the prescribed vs learned framing is a third option that‚Äôs been hiding in plain sight:

Adopt what exists. Extend where needed. Focus learning on what‚Äôs genuinely novel.

The conversation proceeds as if ontology is either an expensive custom artifact (Palantir) or an emergent property of sufficient agent runs (the learned vision). But there‚Äôs twenty years of production ontology work that neither camp is acknowledging.

The Ontologies That Already Exist

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Ontologies That Already Exist‚Äù

Before we talk about learning ontology, it‚Äôs worth acknowledging how much of this work already exists in production systems.

Schema.org

Section titled ‚ÄúSchema.org‚Äù

Schema.org is a collaborative vocabulary for structured data on the web, founded in 2011 by Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, and Yandex. It defines canonical types for the entities that matter:

  • Person
  • Organization
  • Place
  • Event
  • Product
  • CreativeWork
  • And hundreds more

This isn‚Äôt theoretical. It‚Äôs in production across billions of web pages. When you see rich snippets in Google search results‚Äîevent dates, product prices, recipe ratings‚Äîthat‚Äôs Schema.org markup being parsed and displayed.

The types are well-defined. A Person has a name, a jobTitle, a worksFor relationship to an Organization. An Organization has a name, a location, employees. An Event has a startDate, endDate, location, organizer.

This isn‚Äôt a custom ontology someone has to build. It exists. It‚Äôs maintained. It‚Äôs designed for exactly the kind of entity modeling that context graphs require.

WAND and Microsoft Common Data Model

Section titled ‚ÄúWAND and Microsoft Common Data Model‚Äù

Here‚Äôs something surprising: Microsoft‚Äôs Common Data Model‚Äîthe schema that powers Dynamics 365, Power Platform, and much of Microsoft‚Äôs enterprise stack‚Äîwas licensed from WAND.

WAND has been building enterprise taxonomies and ontologies for decades. Their work predates the current AI wave by years. When Microsoft needed a canonical data model for enterprise entities‚ÄîAccount, Contact, Lead, Opportunity, Case, Product, Campaign‚Äîthey didn‚Äôt build it from scratch. They licensed it from people who had already done the work.

CDM defines the entities that enterprise software operates on. Not in theory‚Äîin production, across thousands of organizations running Microsoft‚Äôs business applications.

Industry-Specific Standards

Section titled ‚ÄúIndustry-Specific Standards‚Äù

Beyond Schema.org and CDM, there are industry-specific ontologies refined over years of real-world use:

  • Healthcare: FHIR for clinical data exchange, SNOMED for medical terminology
  • Finance: FIBO for financial instruments and business entities
  • Manufacturing, logistics, energy: Each has domain-specific standards

These aren‚Äôt academic exercises. They‚Äôre production infrastructure. FHIR, for instance, defines how to represent patients, conditions, medications, observations, and clinical workflows.

What Palantir Actually Does

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Palantir Actually Does‚Äù

Daniel Davis made an important observation:

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why everyone thinks Palantir has ontology tech. They do not. They take months, if not years, building it with ‚Äòforward deployed engineers‚Äô. This is not the way to achieve context graphs at scale.‚Äù

This is worth unpacking. Palantir‚Äôs expense isn‚Äôt because ‚Äúprescribed ontologies are hard.‚Äù It‚Äôs because they build custom for every deployment. They‚Äôre not leveraging existing standards‚Äîthey‚Äôre creating bespoke models for each customer‚Äôs specific data landscape.

That‚Äôs a business model choice, not an inherent property of prescribed ontologies. You can adopt Schema.org types, extend with CDM patterns, and add domain-specific entities without spending years on custom modeling.

The Palantir approach is expensive because it‚Äôs bespoke consulting dressed up as platform. The prescribed ontology itself isn‚Äôt the bottleneck. The bottleneck is refusing to leverage what already exists.

Where Learned Ontologies Actually Help

Section titled ‚ÄúWhere Learned Ontologies Actually Help‚Äù

The learned ontology vision conflates two very different problems:

  1. Entity modeling: What types of things exist and how do they relate? (Solved‚Äîor at least solvable with existing standards)
  2. Organizational intelligence: How does this specific organization actually work? What patterns govern decisions? (Genuinely novel, genuinely requires learning)

The entities themselves‚ÄîPerson, Organization, Account, Contact, Event‚Äîdon‚Äôt need to be learned. We know what these are. The types are stable. The core relationships are well-understood.

Where inference genuinely helps is discovering which custom fields actually matter, which relationships get used, which objects are central vs peripheral to how this specific team works. That‚Äôs organizational intelligence on top of a foundation‚Äînot the foundation itself.

Specifically, the organizational-specific layer:

  • Which contacts at an account actually matter for this deal?
  • What‚Äôs the real decision-making process (vs. the org chart)?
  • Which exceptions get approved and which don‚Äôt?
  • What precedents actually govern how decisions are made?

This is tacit knowledge. It‚Äôs not in any ontology because it‚Äôs specific to how this organization operates. It lives in people‚Äôs heads, in Slack threads, in the pattern of which escalations get resolved how.

This is where learning from trajectories makes sense. Not ‚Äúdiscover that Account is an entity‚Äù but ‚Äúdiscover that Sarah Chen is the actual decision-maker even though the CRM says it‚Äôs her boss.‚Äù

The Bootstrap Problem

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Bootstrap Problem‚Äù

Here‚Äôs where the learned ontology vision runs into practical trouble: you can‚Äôt learn from agent trajectories until agents are running effectively. But agents can‚Äôt run effectively without foundational context.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt wait for thousands of agentic RAG runs to ‚Äòdiscover‚Äô that Sarah Chen is a person who works at Acme Corp. You need to know that before agents start reasoning. Otherwise every agent trajectory is fighting the identity resolution problem anew‚Äîand you‚Äôre paying for that confusion in tokens, latency, and errors.‚Äù

The node2vec analogy actually illustrates this. Node2vec learns embeddings from walk patterns over existing edges. It doesn‚Äôt discover nodes and edges from scratch. The graph must exist first.

Agentic workflows operate the same way. The agent harness orchestrates tool calls over a pre-built map. The map is operational context: resolved entities, established relationships, temporal state. Build the map first, then agents walk it effectively.

So how do you bootstrap? The learned ontology vision doesn‚Äôt have a clean answer. ‚ÄúRun agents and let structure emerge‚Äù assumes you have something to run agents over.

The practical answer: adopt existing ontologies as the foundation, then let learning refine and extend.

What‚Äôs Actually Unsolved

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Actually Unsolved‚Äù

If entity modeling is largely solved by existing standards, what‚Äôs actually novel? What‚Äôs the hard problem that context graphs need to address?

It‚Äôs not the nouns. It‚Äôs the temporal and decision layer.

Temporal Validity

Section titled ‚ÄúTemporal Validity‚Äù

Most systems can tell you what‚Äôs true now. Almost none can tell you what was true at a specific point in the past, or how truth evolved over time.

‚ÄúPaula works at Microsoft‚Äù is a fact. But it‚Äôs not a complete fact. When did she start? Does she still work there? What was true in 2022?

This is what Animesh Koratana called the ‚Äúevent clock‚Äù‚Äîthe infrastructure for tracking not just current state, but how state changes over time. Facts with validAt and invalidAt timestamps. The ability to query ‚ÄúWhat did we believe about this account when we made that decision?‚Äù

Existing ontologies don‚Äôt solve this. Schema.org defines Person and Organization, but it doesn‚Äôt have native primitives for ‚Äúthis relationship was true from date X to date Y.‚Äù

Decision Traces

Section titled ‚ÄúDecision Traces‚Äù

Foundation Capital‚Äôs original piece got this right: the reasoning that connects data to action has never been captured as data.

When a renewal agent proposes a 20% discount despite a 10% policy cap, it pulls context from multiple systems. Finance approves. The CRM records ‚Äú20% discount.‚Äù Everything that made that decision legible‚Äîthe inputs, the policy evaluation, the exception route, the approval chain‚Äîdisappears.

Capturing decision traces isn‚Äôt an ontology problem in the traditional sense. It‚Äôs an instrumentation problem. You need to be in the execution path where decisions are committed, capturing not just what happened but why it was allowed to happen.

Fact Resolution

Section titled ‚ÄúFact Resolution‚Äù

When you extract facts from content, you get assertions‚Äînot necessarily truth. Content can be wrong, outdated, or contradictory.

‚ÄúThe customer is renewing‚Äù might appear in a March email. ‚ÄúThe customer churned‚Äù might appear in a September Slack thread. Both are facts extracted from content. But they can‚Äôt both be currently true.

Fact resolution‚Äîdetermining what‚Äôs canonical, what‚Äôs superseded, what‚Äôs corroborated‚Äîis genuinely hard. It requires judgment about temporal validity, source authority, and how later information updates earlier assertions.

Why This Matters for Builders

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy This Matters for Builders‚Äù

The ‚Äúlearned ontology‚Äù framing suggests you should focus on trajectory capture, embedding learning, emergent structure. Build the infrastructure for agents to discover ontology through use.

Kirk Marple suggests something different: focus on what‚Äôs actually unsolved.

  • Entity modeling? Adopt existing standards. Don‚Äôt spend months defining what an Account is. Microsoft already licensed that from WAND.
  • Temporal validity? This is where the work is. Facts that change over time. The ability to query historical state. The event clock.
  • Decision traces? This is where the opportunity is. Being in the execution path. Capturing reasoning as data.
  • Fact resolution? This is where the hard AI problems live. Using LLMs to determine what‚Äôs canonical, what‚Äôs superseded.

The Semantic Web Finally Won

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Semantic Web Finally Won‚Äù

There‚Äôs a through-line in this conversation that deserves acknowledgment. The semantic web community‚ÄîRDF, OWL, linked data‚Äîhas been working on these problems for decades. Schema.org emerged from that tradition.

The vision of machines reasoning over structured, interoperable data wasn‚Äôt invented by the AI crowd in 2024.

What killed adoption wasn‚Äôt the ideas. It was the syntax. RDF, SPARQL, OWL‚Äîthe learning curve was brutal, and most developers never climbed it.

LLMs changed that. They can read JSON-LD natively. They understand Schema.org types from training data. They reason over structured data without needing custom query languages or formal inference engines.

The semantic web‚Äôs concepts won. The syntax lost. And that‚Äôs fine‚ÄîJSON-LD gives you the benefits without the tax.

Three Principles for Context Graph Builders

Section titled ‚ÄúThree Principles for Context Graph Builders‚Äù

  1. Adopt foundations, don‚Äôt reinvent them. The entity modeling problem is solved well enough. Don‚Äôt spend innovation budget rediscovering it.

  2. Build the temporal layer. Facts with validity periods. Queryable history. Time as a first-class dimension.

  3. Focus learning on what‚Äôs genuinely novel. Organizational patterns. Decision dynamics. The tacit knowledge specific to how this organization works. That‚Äôs where trajectories help‚Äîon top of a foundation, not instead of one.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

The context graph vision is achievable. The question is whether we build on what exists or waste years rediscovering it.

The prescribed vs learned dichotomy is too clean. The entities don‚Äôt need to be learned‚Äîthey need to be adopted: Schema.org, CDM, WAND. The work has been done.

What does need to be built is the temporal and decision layer. Facts that change over time. Reasoning captured as data. Resolution that maintains coherence. That‚Äôs genuinely novel. That‚Äôs where the opportunity lives.

Resources

Section titled ‚ÄúResources‚Äù

Referenced Articles

Section titled ‚ÄúReferenced Articles‚Äù
  • Foundation Capital: Context Graphs: AI‚Äôs Trillion-Dollar Opportunity
  • Animesh Koratana: Coordinate Systems Thread
  • Daniel Davis: The Context Graph Manifesto
  • Graphlit: The Context Layer AI Agents Actually Need
  • Graphlit: Building the Event Clock

Standards & Ontologies

Section titled ‚ÄúStandards & Ontologies‚Äù
  • Schema.org - Collaborative vocabulary for structured data
  • Microsoft Common Data Model - Enterprise entity definitions
  • WAND Inc - Enterprise taxonomies and ontologies
  • FHIR - Healthcare data exchange standard
  • FIBO - Financial industry business ontology

Related Reading

Section titled ‚ÄúRelated Reading‚Äù
  • arXiv: Context Graphs as Extension of Knowledge Graphs - June 2024 paper formalizing context graphs with temporal, geographic, and provenance dimensions

item.title: DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning
item.content:encoded:
DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning

Section titled ‚ÄúDataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning‚Äù

In 2025, AI programming has entered a new era. While more developers are using AI to write code, many struggle to move beyond toy projects. The DataWhale Easy-Vibe project addresses this gap with a comprehensive, project-based curriculum for mastering vibe coding - the art of collaborating with AI to build production-ready applications.

Overview

Section titled ‚ÄúOverview‚Äù

Repository: datawhalechina/easy-vibe

Stats:

Easy-Vibe is a Chinese-language open-source curriculum that teaches you to become a one-person team - handling frontend, backend, AI algorithm development, and product management simultaneously through AI-powered development.

What is Vibe Coding?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is Vibe Coding?‚Äù

Vibe coding represents a paradigm shift in software development:

  • Traditional coding: You write every line manually
  • Vibe coding: You orchestrate AI tools to generate, review, and refine code while focusing on product vision and architecture

The key insight: You become the conductor, not the musician.

Why Easy-Vibe Stands Out

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Easy-Vibe Stands Out‚Äù

1. Project-Based Learning Structure

Section titled ‚Äú1. Project-Based Learning Structure‚Äù

Unlike tutorials that focus on isolated concepts, Easy-Vibe uses 9 progressive projects across 3 stages:

Stage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)

Section titled ‚ÄúStage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)‚Äù
  • Project 1: Build a Snake Game - Web AI programming basics, API integration
  • Project 2: Explore AI Tool Boundaries - Prompt engineering, image/video generation APIs
  • Project 3: Dify & Knowledge Base Integration - RAG, workflow orchestration

Stage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)

Section titled ‚ÄúStage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)‚Äù
  • Project 4: Hogwarts Portrait Generator - Frontend prototyping to code, AI IDE basics
  • Project 5: Database to Supabase - JSON, backend services, authentication, edge functions
  • Project 6: Product Thinking First - ProductÊÄùÁª¥, abstraction, user needs

Stage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)

Section titled ‚ÄúStage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)‚Äù
  • Project 7: Modern Application - UI Design
  • Project 8: Modern Application - Feature Design
  • Project 9: Modern Application - Full-Stack Implementation

2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge

Section titled ‚Äú2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge‚Äù

11 supplementary modules covering essential development foundations:

ModuleTopicsDifficulty
Git & GitHubVersion control, collaboration, SSHBeginner
API BasicsHTTP, requests/responses, third-party integrationBeginner
AI DictionaryLLM/image/audio/video models, AI engineering landscapeBeginner
AI IDE & TraeIDE concepts, Trae tool practical guideBeginner
RAG PrinciplesDocument chunking, indexing, enterprise solutionsIntermediate
Zeabur DeploymentWeb app deployment, Zeabur platformIntermediate
CLI AI ToolsTerminal, Claude Code/CodexIntermediate
MCP & SkillsMCP protocol, ClaudeCode Skills, tool extensionsIntermediate
Trae SOLO ModePRD generation, requirements-driven developmentIntermediate
Vibe Coding TasteTDD, checkpoints, constraintsAdvanced
Long-Running ToolsAutomation, task management, CLI stabilityAdvanced

3. Target Audience

Section titled ‚Äú3. Target Audience‚Äù

The curriculum is designed for:

  • Non-technical roles (e.g., product managers) wanting to build AI tools
  • Junior to intermediate developers seeking systematic AI-native development skills
  • Computer science/AI students wanting practical project experience
  • Open source enthusiasts and indie hackers improving development efficiency
  • Enterprise teams prototyping AI applications rapidly

What You‚Äôll Learn

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat You‚Äôll Learn‚Äù

Technical Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúTechnical Skills‚Äù
  • Vibe coding methodology and best practices
  • AI-native application development patterns
  • Git, API, RAG, AI IDE, and deployment tools
  • Frontend, backend, and integration techniques

Product Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúProduct Skills‚Äù
  • Product thinking and user-centric design
  • Requirement abstraction and prioritization
  • Building products that solve real problems

Project Experience

Section titled ‚ÄúProject Experience‚Äù

Complete games, utilities, and product prototypes across different categories

How to Study

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to Study‚Äù

Recommended Approach

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Approach‚Äù
  1. Basic programming experience (any language) required
  2. Complete Projects 0-6 sequentially for full learning progression
  3. Use Extra modules to fill knowledge gaps (Git, API, RAG, deployment)
  4. Practice troubleshooting independently before checking solutions

Modern Setup

Section titled ‚ÄúModern Setup‚Äù

In any AI IDE (VS Code, Cursor, Trae), simply ask:

  • ‚úÖ Completed: Projects 1-6, Extra 1-7
  • üöß In Progress: Projects 7-9, Extra 8-11

Roadmap

Section titled ‚ÄúRoadmap‚Äù

  • Adding iOS platform vibe coding content
  • Polishing English version translations

Contributing

Section titled ‚ÄúContributing‚Äù

Easy-Vibe welcomes contributions:

  1. Issues: Report problems or suggest improvements
  2. Pull Requests: Submit code/documentation changes
  3. New Projects: Follow DataWhale‚Äôs open source project guidelines

Contact the support team via:

Key Contributors

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

DataWhale‚Äôs Easy-Vibe fills a critical gap in AI programming education by providing:

  1. Structured progression from beginner to advanced
  2. Hands-on projects that build real skills
  3. Comprehensive coverage of both technical and product thinking
  4. Active community support and contribution

Whether you‚Äôre a product manager wanting to build tools, a developer upskilling for the AI era, or a student seeking practical experience, Easy-Vibe offers a clear path from zero to AI-native product development.

item.title: Issue: Content Loss Caused by GLM Quotas Limit
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

In an effort to accelerate content creation, an experiment was conducted to write multiple blog posts simultaneously using Claude Code. However, this aggressive parallelization strategy hit a bottleneck: the GLM API quota limits. This unexpected constraint led to content loss, with several blog posts failing to complete.

The Experiment: Aggressive Parallelization

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Experiment: Aggressive Parallelization‚Äù

To maximize efficiency, over 10 instances of Claude Code shells were launched in parallel. The goal was to generate a batch of blog posts concurrently.

The Issue: Hitting the Ceiling

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Issue: Hitting the Ceiling‚Äù

As the multiple instances began generating content, they rapidly consumed the available API quota. The GLM API, having strict rate limits and quotas, blocked further requests once the threshold was reached.

The system immediately flagged the quota violation.

The Consequence: Content Loss

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Consequence: Content Loss‚Äù

The direct result of hitting the API limit was that the generation process for several blog posts was abruptly terminated. This left the files in an incomplete state, effectively resulting in content loss.

Checking the WeChat Official Account Draft Box confirmed that the articles were not successfully fully generated or uploaded.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

While parallel processing is a powerful technique for efficiency, it must be balanced against external constraints like API quotas. Future batch processing will need to implement rate limiting or sequential queuing to ensure stability and data integrity.

item.title: Librarian: Local CLI Tool for Coding Agents to Search Developer Documentation
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

AI coding assistants are powerful, but they often work with outdated or incomplete documentation. Librarian solves this problem by fetching and searching up-to-date developer documentation locally on your machine, giving AI agents real context so they stop guessing and write better code.

GitHub: https://github.com/iannuttall/librarian

Librarian supports both GitHub repositories and public websites, making it a versatile tool for keeping your AI assistant‚Äôs knowledge fresh and accurate.

Key Features

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features‚Äù

Local Documentation Management

Section titled ‚ÄúLocal Documentation Management‚Äù
  • Fetch docs from GitHub repos - Clone and index documentation from any public repository
  • Crawl public websites - Automatically discover and index docs from llms.txt, sitemap.xml, or robots.txt
  • Hybrid search - Combine word search with semantic vector search for best results
  • Version-aware - Track documentation versions to avoid mixed results

AI Agent Integration

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Agent Integration‚Äù
  • MCP Server - Built-in Model Context Protocol server for seamless integration
  • Agent skills - Pre-built skills for Codex, Claude Code, and Factory
  • JSON output - Machine-readable results for automated workflows

Flexible Search Modes

Section titled ‚ÄúFlexible Search Modes‚Äù
  • Hybrid search - Word + meaning (default, most accurate)
  • Word search - Traditional keyword matching
  • Vector search - Pure semantic similarity

Quick Start

Section titled ‚ÄúQuick Start‚Äù

Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation‚Äù

During setup, you can choose to install globally. If global install is selected, use librarian directly. Otherwise, use ./librarian.

Adding Documentation Sources

Section titled ‚ÄúAdding Documentation Sources‚Äù

From GitHub Repositories

Section titled ‚ÄúFrom GitHub Repositories‚Äù

From Public Websites

Section titled ‚ÄúFrom Public Websites‚Äù

Ingesting and Searching

Section titled ‚ÄúIngesting and Searching‚Äù

Advanced Usage

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvanced Usage‚Äù

Library Detection

Section titled ‚ÄúLibrary Detection‚Äù

When working in a repository, Librarian can detect which documentation versions are relevant:

This returns version labels you can use to scope your searches.

Library Search

Section titled ‚ÄúLibrary Search‚Äù

Find available libraries and their versions:

Useful Commands

Section titled ‚ÄúUseful Commands‚Äù

MCP Server Integration

Section titled ‚ÄúMCP Server Integration‚Äù

Librarian includes a built-in MCP server for integration with AI coding assistants:

Available MCP Tools:

  • search - Search documentation with mode options (word/vector/hybrid)
  • library - Find and list libraries/versions
  • get - Retrieve specific documentation

Agent Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúAgent Skills‚Äù

Librarian provides pre-built skills using progressive disclosure (only name/description load at startup).

For Codex

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Codex‚Äù
  • Direct invocation: $librarian or /skills in CLI
  • Note: Codex web and iOS don‚Äôt support direct invocation yet

For Claude Code

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Claude Code‚Äù

For Factory

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Factory‚Äù

Configuration

Section titled ‚ÄúConfiguration‚Äù

Configuration file: ~/.config/librarian/config.yml

Important Notes

Section titled ‚ÄúImportant Notes‚Äù
  • Setup downloads a local embedding model for vector search
  • Public GitHub repos don‚Äôt require a token
  • Website crawling auto-detects CSR/SPA sites and uses headless Chrome
  • Chrome is auto-detected but can be manually configured
  • Run librarian setup to verify Chrome availability
  • If librarian command doesn‚Äôt work, use ./librarian

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

1. Version Scoping

Section titled ‚Äú1. Version Scoping‚Äù

To avoid mixed results from different documentation versions, always scope searches:

2. Regular Updates

Section titled ‚Äú2. Regular Updates‚Äù

Documentation changes frequently. Keep your local copies fresh:

3. Source Organization

Section titled ‚Äú3. Source Organization‚Äù

Use descriptive names when adding sources and clean up unused ones:

4. Seed List

Section titled ‚Äú4. Seed List‚Äù

Librarian includes a built-in seed list of popular documentation sources:

The default seed list is in data/libraries.yml in the repository.

Use Cases

Section titled ‚ÄúUse Cases‚Äù

For AI-Assisted Development

Section titled ‚ÄúFor AI-Assisted Development‚Äù
  • Accurate API references - Give AI agents exact documentation instead of outdated training data
  • Framework-specific patterns - Search framework docs for best practices
  • Troubleshooting - Find relevant error messages and solutions from official docs

For Developer Teams

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Developer Teams‚Äù
  • Consistent documentation access - Ensure all team members reference the same doc versions
  • Offline capability - Access documentation without internet
  • Fast search - Local search is faster than web browsing

Technical Details

Section titled ‚ÄúTechnical Details‚Äù
  • Language: TypeScript (99.9%)
  • Package Manager: Bun
  • Embedding Model: Local (downloaded during setup)
  • Crawler: Headless Chrome for SPA/CSR sites

Resources

Section titled ‚ÄúResources‚Äù
  • GitHub Repository
  • Documentation
  • MCP Server Info
  • Issue Tracker

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Librarian addresses a critical gap in AI-assisted development: keeping documentation context current and accurate. By running locally and supporting both GitHub repos and public websites, it gives AI coding agents the real-time context they need to write better code instead of guessing based on outdated training data.

Whether you‚Äôre using Claude Code, Codex, or building custom AI agents, Librarian provides the infrastructure for accurate, up-to-date documentation search.

Keywords: Librarian, AI coding, documentation search, CLI tool, MCP server, developer tools, local search, vector search

Why Many People Still Don't Use AI In-Depth: A Reflection on Purpose and Agency
item.content:encoded:
Why Many People Still Don‚Äôt Use AI In-Depth

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Many People Still Don‚Äôt Use AI In-Depth‚Äù

Source: @naki2012 | Published: January 5, 2026

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

If you observe carefully, you‚Äôll notice a phenomenon:

People who genuinely ‚Äúfeel AI is useless‚Äù often can‚Äôt articulate what they want to accomplish.

This is not a coincidence.

AI Is Not a Tool Everyone Needs

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Is Not a Tool Everyone Needs‚Äù

Let‚Äôs start with a politically incorrect truth:

AI is not a ‚Äúproductivity equalizer.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not water, electricity, or air. Nor is it an emotional consumer good like short-form video.

AI is more like an amplifier‚Äîit only works on what already exists.

  • People with problems use AI to break them down more clearly
  • People with ideas use AI to push them further
  • People with direction use AI to compress paths and reduce trial and error

What about those without these things?

For them, AI truly is ‚Äúuseless.‚Äù

Why ‚ÄúPeople Without Ideas‚Äù Don‚Äôt Need AI

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy ‚ÄúPeople Without Ideas‚Äù Don‚Äôt Need AI‚Äù

AI has aÂÜ∑ÈÖ∑ prerequisite:

You must first know what you want to do.

AI won‚Äôt decide your life direction. It won‚Äôt generate desires for you.

It only responds to:

  • Problems
  • Hypotheses
  • Goals
  • Paths

Yet many people‚Äôs daily state is:

  • Passively binge-watching shows
  • Passively scrolling videos
  • Passively working
  • Passively waiting for opportunities

Ask them what they want, and after thinking they say:

‚ÄúI want to get rich overnight.‚Äù

This statement itself declares AI‚Äôs uselessness.

Why ‚ÄúGet Rich Quick‚Äù Is AI‚Äôs Nemesis

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy ‚ÄúGet Rich Quick‚Äù Is AI‚Äôs Nemesis‚Äù

Because it‚Äôs not a goal‚Äîit‚Äôs an escapist fantasy.

Its subtext is:

  • I don‚Äôt want to think about the process
  • I don‚Äôt want to own the journey
  • I only want the result

AI is precisely the opposite.

AI excels at exactly one thing:

Making ‚Äúwhat you‚Äôre already thinking about‚Äù clearer.

If you think about nothing, hoping the world suddenly changes‚Äîwhat you need isn‚Äôt AI. It‚Äôs luck, lottery tickets, or miracles.

Binge-Watching vs AI: Two Opposite Systems

Section titled ‚ÄúBinge-Watching vs AI: Two Opposite Systems‚Äù

Many don‚Äôt realize:

AI is the first mass technology that doesn‚Äôt serve escapism.

Binge-watching shows and scrolling short videos share:

  • No intention needed
  • No choices needed
  • No responsibility needed

You just ‚Äúcontinue to next.‚Äù

AI‚Äôs interface seems gentle, but its core is cold:

  • You don‚Äôt ask, it doesn‚Äôt move
  • You ask unclearly, it exposes your confusion
  • You don‚Äôt give direction, it spins in place

Some instinctively reject it. Not because it‚Äôs hard to use, but because it reflects their empty-spinning state.

Why Not Using AI Is Becoming a ‚ÄúGeneration Gap‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Not Using AI Is Becoming a ‚ÄúGeneration Gap‚Äù‚Äù

Over the past year, AI hasn‚Äôt been ‚Äúimproving efficiency‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs been restructuring cognitive division of labor:

HumanAI
Judgment, stance, trade-offsExpansion, verification, parallel execution, compression

Not using AI means:

  • All thinking runs only in your own brain
  • All trial and error costs your personal time
  • Once problem complexity rises, you immediately struggle

Short-term, they can still work. But long-term, their ceiling is locked.

A Less Polite but Real Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúA Less Polite but Real Conclusion‚Äù

It‚Äôs not that AI abandoned many people.

Rather, many people were never on the path that ‚Äúneeds AI‚Äù from the start.

They don‚Äôt need an amplifier because there‚Äôs nothing worth amplifying.

What they need is:

  • Distraction
  • Anesthesia
  • Miracles

Not:

  • Thinking
  • Reasoning
  • Action paths

The Final Line (The Boundary)

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Final Line (The Boundary)‚Äù

AI belongs only to those who have started taking responsibility for their lives.

If you‚Äôre already thinking:

  • What do I want to change?
  • What do I want to advance?
  • Where am I stuck?

Then AI becomes your external brain.

If you‚Äôre still at:

  • ‚ÄúWhatever, doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see what luck brings‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWait for opportunity‚Äù

Then saying AI is useless is completely correct.

Key Insights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Insights‚Äù
InsightImplication
AI as AmplifierIt enhances what exists, doesn‚Äôt create from nothing
The PrerequisiteYou must know what you want before AI can help
Escapism vs EngagementAI requires active participation, unlike passive entertainment
Cognitive DivisionHumans judge; AI expands, verifies, and compresses
The BoundaryAI serves those taking responsibility for their direction

The Deeper Question

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Deeper Question‚Äù

This reflection raises an important question for all of us:

Are we using AI, or avoiding the mirror it holds up?

AI doesn‚Äôt just amplify our productivity‚Äîit amplifies our clarity of purpose. Those who find it useless may be discovering something uncomfortable: they may not have a purpose to amplify.

References

Section titled ‚ÄúReferences‚Äù
  • Original Thread by @naki2012
